title: Must be willing to change ourselves
text:
Must be willing to change ourselves 0 comments 
The other evening, reflecting on some family concerns, I whispered my prayers into the darkness, as I generally do, "God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change (and then I name some very specific people or things that I fell compelled to control), the courage to change the things I can (which is always me and the way I am responding) and the wisdom to know the difference." One reason I appreciate the Serenity Prayer so much is that it shifts my focus from the "gimmees" and do-fers-mes" to the quiet acceptance of simply being and loving friends, family, and enemies. Letting go and letting God. 
That night as I worried and stewed about "the problem" I felt called to insert the name of a loved one in the Serenity Prayer. "God grant (and I filled in her name) the serenity to accept the things she cannot change, the courage to change the things she can, and the wisdom to know the difference. Help her to live one day at a time, to enjoy one moment at a time, to accept these current difficulties and hardships as her pathway to peace of mind, body, and spirit.
